1.title: Simplr Router
1.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
1.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

2.title: Simplr Router
2.headline: Small
2.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

3.title: Simplr Router
3.headline: Easy to transition into
3.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

4.title: Simplr Router
4.headline: Web Component focused
4.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

5.title: Simplr Router
5.headline: Customizable
5.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

6.title: Simplr Router
6.headline: Performant
6.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

29.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
29.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
29.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

30.title: Customizing: Middleware
30.headline: Customizing: Middleware
30.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

31.title: Customizing: Middleware
31.headline: Reactive events
31.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

32.title: Customizing: Middleware
32.headline: Overriding events
32.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

50.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
50.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
50.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

51.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
51.headline: Using an outlet
51.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

54.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
54.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
54.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

63.title: Getting started: Using a starter
63.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
63.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

64.title: Getting started: Using a starter
64.headline: Initial setup
64.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

65.title: Getting started: Using a starter
65.headline: Installing the router
65.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

123.title: API: Route
123.headline: API: Route
123.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

124.title: API: Router Options
124.headline: API: Router Options
124.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

147.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
147.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
147.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

148.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
148.headline: Using an outlet
148.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

150.title: Customizing: Middleware
150.headline: Customizing: Middleware
150.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

151.title: Customizing: Middleware
151.headline: Reactive events
151.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

152.title: Customizing: Middleware
152.headline: Overriding events
152.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

176.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
176.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
176.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter

188.title: Getting started: Using a starter
188.headline: Initial setup
188.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

189.title: Getting started: Using a starter
189.headline: Installing the router
189.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

198.title: API: Route
198.headline: API: Route
198.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

199.title: API: Router Options
199.headline: API: Router Options
199.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

279.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
279.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
279.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

280.title: API: Route
280.headline: API: Route
280.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

281.title: API: Router Options
281.headline: API: Router Options
281.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

282.title: API: Router
282.headline: API: Router
282.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 



































Name Type Description   init() Function() Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Add middleware to Simplr Router.  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Returns the breadcrumbs for the current route.  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Returns the current view.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

284.title: Customizing: Middleware
284.headline: Customizing: Middleware
284.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

285.title: Customizing: Middleware
285.headline: Reactive events
285.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

286.title: Customizing: Middleware
286.headline: Overriding events
286.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

l.title: Getting started: Using a starter
l.headline: Initial setup
l.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

m.headline: Installing the router
m.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

w.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
w.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
w.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content.

x.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
x.headline: Using an outlet
x.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior.

y.title: Getting started: Your first setup

z.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
z.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
z.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

3m.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
3m.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
3m.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

3n.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
3n.headline: Using an outlet
3n.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

3q.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
3q.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
3q.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

If you are more experiences, you could look into the Your first Setup  -section and read through the recipes.

4d.title: Customizing: Middleware
4d.headline: Customizing: Middleware
4d.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

4e.title: Customizing: Middleware
4e.headline: Reactive events
4e.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

4f.title: Customizing: Middleware
4f.headline: Overriding events
4f.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

4p.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
4p.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

4q.title: Getting started: Using a starter
4q.headline: Initial setup
4q.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

4r.title: Getting started: Using a starter
4r.headline: Installing the router
4r.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

9a.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
9a.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
9a.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

9y.title: Customizing: Middleware
9y.headline: Customizing: Middleware
9y.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

9z.title: Customizing: Middleware
9z.headline: Reactive events
9z.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

a0.title: Customizing: Middleware
a0.headline: Overriding events
a0.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

ak.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
ak.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
ak.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

al.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
al.headline: Using an outlet
al.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

dc.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
dc.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
dc.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

dd.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
dd.headline: Using an outlet
dd.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

dg.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
dg.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
dg.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

e2.title: API: Router Options
e2.headline: API: Router Options

e4.title: Customizing: Middleware
e4.headline: Customizing: Middleware
e4.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

e5.title: Customizing: Middleware
e5.headline: Reactive events
e5.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

e6.title: Customizing: Middleware
e6.headline: Overriding events
e6.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

fg.title: API: Router Options
fg.headline: API: Router Options
fg.body:
Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

gu.headline: API: Router Options
gu.body:
Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

gx.title: Customizing: Middleware
gx.headline: Customizing: Middleware
gx.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

gy.title: Customizing: Middleware
gy.headline: Reactive events
gy.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

gz.title: Customizing: Middleware
gz.headline: Overriding events
gz.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

h9.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

ha.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

hj.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
hj.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
hj.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

hk.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
hk.headline: Using an outlet
hk.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

hn.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
hn.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
hn.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

i1.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

i2.title: Simplr Router
i2.headline: Small
i2.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

i3.title: Simplr Router
i3.headline: Easy to transition into
i3.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

i4.title: Simplr Router
i4.headline: Web Component focused
i4.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

i5.title: Simplr Router
i5.headline: Customizable
i5.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

i6.title: Simplr Router
i6.headline: Performant
i6.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior.

kh.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
kh.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
kh.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute

l6.title: Customizing: Middleware
l6.headline: Customizing: Middleware
l6.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

l7.title: Customizing: Middleware
l7.headline: Reactive events
l7.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

l8.title: Customizing: Middleware
l8.headline: Overriding events
l8.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

lh.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

li.title: Getting started: Using a starter
li.headline: Initial setup
li.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

lj.title: Getting started: Using a starter
lj.headline: Installing the router
lj.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

lt.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
lt.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
lt.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

lu.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
lu.headline: Using an outlet
lu.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

om.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
om.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
om.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

on.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
on.headline: Using an outlet
on.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior.

    Edit this page on GitHub!

oq.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
oq.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
oq.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

pf.title: Customizing: Middleware
pf.headline: Customizing: Middleware
pf.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

pg.title: Customizing: Middleware
pg.headline: Reactive events
pg.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

ph.title: Customizing: Middleware
ph.headline: Overriding events
ph.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

s4.title: Guides
s4.headline: Guides
s4.body:
This section of the documentation provides some examples, recipes and references for using Simplr Router. 
If you are new to Web Components, you should start from Using a Starter  
If you are more experiences, you could look into the Your first Setup  -section and read through the recipes.

s6.body:

s7.title: API: Router Options
s7.headline: API: Router Options
s7.body:
Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

s9.title: Customizing: Middleware
s9.headline: Customizing: Middleware
s9.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

sa.title: Customizing: Middleware
sa.headline: Reactive events
sa.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

sb.title: Customizing: Middleware
sb.headline: Overriding events
sb.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

sj.title: Getting started: Using a starter
sj.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
sj.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

sk.title: Getting started: Using a starter
sk.headline: Initial setup
sk.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

sl.title: Getting started: Using a starter
sl.headline: Installing the router
sl.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

options and recipes, check out the recipes  section. For a thorough look into the actual API
behing Simplr Router, check out the docs .

sv.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
sv.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
sv.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

sw.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
sw.headline: Using an outlet
sw.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

sz.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
sz.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
sz.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

v0.title: API: Route
v0.headline: API: Route
v0.body:
| Name      | Type                | Description      |
| --------- | ------------------- | ---------------- | --- |
| path      | string              |                  |
| component | string              |                  |
| name      | string              |                  |
| import    | Function            |                  |
| guard     | Function            |                  |
| routes    | SimplrRoute[]       |                  |
| slots     | [x: string]: string | Function         |     |
| pattern   | [x: string]: string |                  |
| redirect  | string              | { name: string } |     | 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

vp.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
vp.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
vp.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

vq.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
vq.headline: Using an outlet
vq.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

vt.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
vt.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
vt.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

wg.title: API: Router Options
wg.headline: API: Router Options
wg.body:
Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

wi.title: Customizing: Middleware
wi.headline: Customizing: Middleware
wi.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

wj.title: Customizing: Middleware
wj.headline: Reactive events
wj.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

wk.title: Customizing: Middleware
wk.headline: Overriding events
wk.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

wu.title: Getting started: Using a starter
wu.headline: Initial setup
wu.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

wv.title: Getting started: Using a starter
wv.headline: Installing the router
wv.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

ze.title: Customizing: Middleware
ze.headline: Overriding events
ze.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

zy.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
zy.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
zy.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

zz.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
zz.headline: Using an outlet
zz.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior.

10r.title: Customizing: Middleware
10r.headline: Customizing: Middleware
10r.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

10s.title: Customizing: Middleware
10s.headline: Reactive events
10s.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

10t.headline: Overriding events

These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation
