11h.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
11h.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
11h.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

14b.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
14b.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
14b.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

14w.title: API: Route
14w.headline: API: Route
14w.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

14y.title: API: Router Options
14y.headline: API: Router Options
14y.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

15b.title: Getting started: Using a starter
15b.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
15b.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

15c.title: Getting started: Using a starter
15c.headline: Initial setup
15c.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

15m.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
15m.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
15m.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

15n.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
15n.headline: Using an outlet
15n.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

16g.title: Customizing: Middleware
16g.headline: Customizing: Middleware
16g.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

16h.title: Customizing: Middleware
16h.headline: Reactive events
16h.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

16i.title: Customizing: Middleware
16i.headline: Overriding events
16i.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

19b.title: API: Router
19b.headline: API: Router
19b.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

19c.title: Customizing: Changing routing root
19c.headline: Customizing: Changing routing root

19d.title: Customizing: Middleware
19d.headline: Customizing: Middleware
19d.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

19e.title: Customizing: Middleware
19e.headline: Reactive events
19e.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

19f.title: Customizing: Middleware
19f.headline: Overriding events
19f.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

19g.headline: Using a middleware

19n.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

19o.title: Getting started: Using a starter
19o.headline: Initial setup
19o.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

19p.title: Getting started: Using a starter
19p.headline: Installing the router
19p.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

19y.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
19y.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
19y.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

19z.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
19z.headline: Using an outlet
19z.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1a2.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1a2.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1a2.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

1ck.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1ck.headline: Initial setup
1ck.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

1cl.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1cl.headline: Installing the router
1cl.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

Create a link to navigate to the page

1cu.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1cu.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1cu.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1cv.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1cv.headline: Using an outlet
1cv.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1cy.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1cy.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1cy.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1db.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

1dc.title: Simplr Router
1dc.headline: Small
1dc.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

1dd.title: Simplr Router
1dd.headline: Easy to transition into
1dd.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

1de.title: Simplr Router
1de.headline: Web Component focused
1de.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

1df.title: Simplr Router
1df.headline: Customizable
1df.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

1dg.title: Simplr Router
1dg.headline: Performant
1dg.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

1dk.title: API: Route
1dk.headline: API: Route
1dk.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1dl.title: API: Router Options
1dl.headline: API: Router Options
1dl.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1dm.title: API: Router
1dm.headline: API: Router
1dm.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 




















Name Type Description   init() Function Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating  changeView() Function({ path?, name?, hash? }) Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1do.title: Customizing: Middleware
1do.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1do.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1dp.title: Customizing: Middleware
1dp.headline: Reactive events
1dp.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1dq.title: Customizing: Middleware
1dq.headline: Overriding events
1dq.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1g8.headline: Small
1g8.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

1g9.title: Simplr Router
1g9.headline: Easy to transition into

1ga.title: Simplr Router
1ga.headline: Web Component focused
1ga.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

1gb.title: Simplr Router
1gb.headline: Customizable
1gb.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

1gc.headline: Performant

1gg.title: API: Route
1gg.headline: API: Route
1gg.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1gh.title: API: Router Options
1gh.headline: API: Router Options
1gh.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1gi.title: API: Router
1gi.headline: API: Router
1gi.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 




















Name Type Description   init() Function Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function({ path?, name?, hash? }) Change view to given path or named route.

1gk.title: Customizing: Middleware
1gk.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1gk.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1gl.title: Customizing: Middleware
1gl.headline: Reactive events
1gl.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1gm.title: Customizing: Middleware
1gm.headline: Overriding events
1gm.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1gv.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1gv.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
1gv.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

1gw.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1gw.headline: Initial setup
1gw.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

1gx.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1gx.headline: Installing the router
1gx.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

1h6.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1h6.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1h6.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1h7.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1h7.headline: Using an outlet
1h7.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1ha.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1ha.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1ha.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1jg.title: Customizing: Middleware
1jg.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1jg.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1jh.title: Customizing: Middleware
1jh.headline: Reactive events
1jh.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1ji.title: Customizing: Middleware
1ji.headline: Overriding events
1ji.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

1k2.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1k2.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1k2.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1k3.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1k3.headline: Using an outlet
1k3.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1k6.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1k6.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1k6.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1kr.title: API: Route
1kr.headline: API: Route
1kr.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to

Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1mo.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1mo.headline: Using an outlet
1mo.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior.

1n2.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1n2.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1n2.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1no.title: API: Route
1no.headline: API: Route
1no.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

Type name: SimplrRouter 

























Name Type Description   init() Function Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Change view to given path or named route.

1ns.title: Customizing: Middleware
1ns.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1ns.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1nt.title: Customizing: Middleware
1nt.headline: Reactive events
1nt.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1nu.title: Customizing: Middleware
1nu.headline: Overriding events
1nu.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1qi.title: Guides
1qi.headline: Guides
1qi.body:
This section of the documentation provides some examples, recipes and references for using Simplr Router. 
If you are new to Web Components, you should start from Using a Starter  
If you are more experiences, you could look into the Your first Setup  -section and read through the recipes.

1qk.title: API: Route
1qk.headline: API: Route
1qk.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1ql.title: API: Router Options
1ql.headline: API: Router Options
1ql.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1qm.title: API: Router
1qm.headline: API: Router
1qm.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 






























Name Type Description   init() Function Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Change view to given path or named route.  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): returns SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Change view to given path or named route.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1qo.title: Customizing: Middleware
1qo.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1qo.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1qp.title: Customizing: Middleware
1qp.headline: Reactive events
1qp.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1qq.title: Customizing: Middleware
1qq.headline: Overriding events
1qq.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1qz.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1qz.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
1qz.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

1r0.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1r0.headline: Initial setup
1r0.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

1r1.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1r1.headline: Installing the router
1r1.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

1r5.headline: Adding views

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

behing Simplr Router, check out the docs .

1ra.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1ra.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1ra.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1rb.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1rb.headline: Using an outlet
1rb.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1re.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1re.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1re.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1th.title: API: Router Options
1th.headline: API: Router Options
1th.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

1ti.headline: API: Router
1ti.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 



































Name Type Description   init() Function() Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Change view to given path or named route.  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Change view to given path or named route.  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Change view to given path or named route.

1tk.title: Customizing: Middleware
1tk.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1tk.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1tl.title: Customizing: Middleware
1tl.headline: Reactive events
1tl.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1tm.title: Customizing: Middleware
1tm.headline: Overriding events
1tm.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1tv.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1tv.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
1tv.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

1tw.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1tw.headline: Initial setup
1tw.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

1tx.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1tx.headline: Installing the router
1tx.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

options and recipes, check out the recipes  section. For a thorough look into the actual API
behing Simplr Router, check out the docs .

    Edit this page on GitHub!

1u6.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1u6.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1u6.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1u7.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1u7.headline: Using an outlet
1u7.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1u8.title: Getting started: Your first setup

1u9.title: Recipes: Child routes
1u9.headline: Recipes: Child routes

1ua.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1ua.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1ua.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1uq.headline: Web Component focused
1uq.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

1ur.headline: Customizable
1ur.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

1us.headline: Performant

An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

npm  init @open-wc

an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need.

1x2.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1x2.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1x2.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1x3.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1x3.headline: Using an outlet
1x3.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1x6.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1x6.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1x6.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1xs.title: API: Route
1xs.headline: API: Route
1xs.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1xt.title: API: Router Options

1xt.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

1xu.headline: API: Router
1xu.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 



































Name Type Description   init() Function() Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Add middleware to Simplr Router  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Returns the breadcrumbs for the current route  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Change view to given path or named route.

1xw.title: Customizing: Middleware
1xw.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1xw.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1xx.title: Customizing: Middleware
1xx.headline: Reactive events
1xx.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1xy.title: Customizing: Middleware
1xy.headline: Overriding events
1xy.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1zy.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
1zy.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

1zz.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
1zz.headline: Using an outlet
1zz.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

20o.title: API: Route
20o.headline: API: Route
20o.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

20p.title: API: Router Options
20p.headline: API: Router Options
20p.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.

20q.title: API: Router
20q.headline: API: Router
20q.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 



































Name Type Description   init() Function() Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Add middleware to Simplr Router.  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Returns the breadcrumbs for the current route.  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Returns the current view.

20s.title: Customizing: Middleware
20s.headline: Customizing: Middleware
20s.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

20t.title: Customizing: Middleware
20t.headline: Reactive events
20t.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

20u.title: Customizing: Middleware
20u.headline: Overriding events
20u.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

20v.headline: Using a middleware

21i.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
21i.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
21i.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

22j.title: Getting started: Using a starter
22j.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
22j.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

22k.title: Getting started: Using a starter
22k.headline: Initial setup
22k.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

22l.title: Getting started: Using a starter
22l.headline: Installing the router
22l.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

25h.title: Getting started: Using a starter
25h.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
25h.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

25i.title: Getting started: Using a starter
25i.headline: Initial setup
25i.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

25j.title: Getting started: Using a starter
25j.headline: Installing the router
25j.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

25n.body:
Next we will want to do some actual routing. This requires a few steps: 

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

25r.body:
You're now all set to start building your application on top of Simplr Router. For more configuration
options and recipes, check out the recipes  section. For a thorough look into the actual API
behing Simplr Router, check out the docs .

25s.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
25s.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
25s.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

25t.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
25t.headline: Using an outlet
25t.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

25w.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
25w.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
25w.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .
